section.title: Modals (and verbs with similar meanings)
section.sectiontitle: Use don't have to for lack of obligation, and must not for an obligation not to do something.
section.text1a: We don't have to be there until 2.30pm
section.text2a: You mustn't talk to him like that.
section.sectiontitle2: Use should/ought to for advice, or a recommendation.
section.text4a: You ought to see the castle before you leave.

section.title: Modals (and verbs with similar meanings)
section.text1a: Guests should not smoke in the bedrooms.
section.text2a: Should we lock both the doors?
section.sectiontitle2: Use should for expectation. Use should with thinking verbs to make them less direct.
section.text4a: I shouldn't think the meeting will take long.

section.title: Modals (and verbs with similar meanings)
section.text1a: They'll be here in a minute.
section.text2a: I won't stop until I get what I want.
section.sectiontitle2: Use may/might for possibility. Use might as well as the last option, when the speaker is not keen.
section.text4a: We might as well just pay the bill.

section.title: Modals (and verbs with similar meanings)
section.sectiontitle: Use must for certainty. Need behaves like a normal verb.
section.text2a: Do you need to speak to the doctor?
section.text3a: They were supposed to deliver the parcel this morning.

section.title: Modals (and verbs with similar meanings)
section.sectiontitle: be bound to is for a prediction of certainty.
section.text1a: He's bound to get the job he wants.
section.sectiontitle2: be likely to do/be is for probability.
section.text3a: Children living in rural areas are likely to move to the city as adults.
